In the story "Saving Tobe," Osvaldo runs into the woods primarily to get help for Tobe, who has fallen into the river. This act demonstrates his sense of responsibility and quick thinking in an emergency.

After Tobe falls into the water, Osvaldo, realizing the severity of the situation, immediately seeks assistance. While fear of getting into trouble might have been a contributing factor to his distress, his main objective in running into the woods was to find someone who could aid in rescuing Tobe.
